| Section3 = {{Chembox Hazards MainHazards = FlashPt = Autoignition = }}
}} 'Tryptophan' (IUPAC-IUBMB abbreviation: 'Trp' or 'W'; IUPAC abbreviation:
L-Trp or D-Trp; sold for medical use as 'Tryptan') is one of the 22
standard amino acids and an essential amino acid in the human diet. It is
encoded in the standard genetic code as the codon UGG. Only the L-stereoisomer
of tryptophan is used in structural or enzyme proteins, but the D-stereoisomer
is occasionally found in naturally produced peptides (for example, the marine
venom peptide contryphan). The distinguishing
structural characteristic of tryptophan is that it contains an indole
functional group. It is an essential amino acid, as demonstrated by its growth
effects on rats.
